options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: More in-depth understanding of current debate about technology and its impacts on the labor force

I learned a great deal about technology, innovation and R&D. Using the microeconomics of technology, we analyzed various developments in technology from patent law, UBI, robot taxes, income inequality, and the automation revolution. I learned a lot about labor economics, especially, in the context of technology.

I learned an immense amount of the impacts of technological innovation on markets, society, and the different groups of people that operate within them. While the course refreshed concepts from microeconomics, macroeconomics, game theory, and statistics, the core course did not feel like a slog of math., Instead, I learned about how we can visualize and model who wins and loses when technological progress increases efficiency for different firms.
A more holistic understanding of economic forces in the realm of technology.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
strengths - Burak is a wonderful and caring professor

weaknesses - He sometimes went over class time

There are several strengths! First and foremost, Burak is an incredibly thoughtful, engaging, and dedicated professor. It's obvious he loves teaching the material and this passion made going to class at 9am easy. He is one of my favorite professors I have had at Yale thus far. In addition, the class and syllabus structure builds on itself and gives a great synopsis of recent research and findings in the world of AI and robots. No weaknesses.

This course was very well-rounded and incredibly helpful for students. Professor Unveren held office hours, discussed psets with us, and made sure we were understanding course material throughout each lecture. I genuinely cannot think of any substantial course weaknesses.
I loved the structure of the course! I especially liked the integration of real-life examples.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The office hours and virtual class times worked well

Burak's use of a separate camera and dry erase board were extremely effective. He could also then switch back to his computer camera during more seminar-like discussions. No improvements I can think of!
Virtual office hours were incredibly helpful.
Professor Unveren was very willing to make more time for anyone who needed extra help in class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! It was an interesting class with a great professor. You can't find a seminar better than this one at Yale.
Yes! It has been my favorite EP&E class! Material is fascinating and the expectations are extremely reasonable and flexible.

I would highly recommend this course to another student, especially for those who wants to apply core economic ideas into a field of research that evaluates the ethical impacts of machine learning, industrialization, and artificial intelligence. We review a significant amount of interesting scholarly work and news articles that supplement the course material very well.
Yes! Professor Unveren is very passionate about this subject.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Was technically a lecture, but felt like a seminar!
